unnormalised: **Question: What are some yoga practices I can easily incorporate into my daily routine?**
normalised: **Question: What are some yoga practices I can easily incorporate into my daily routine?**

unnormalised: Okay, so you want to get into yoga? That's fantastic! It's truly helped so many, including me, feel more grounded and energetic. No need to become a full-fledged sanyasi overnight! Start small.
normalised: Okay, so you want to get into yoga? That's fantastic! It's truly helped so many, including me, feel more grounded and energetic. No need to become a full-fledged sanyasi overnight! Start small.

unnormalised: Firstly, Sun Salutations (Surya Namaskar) are a classic. Even just 5 rounds in the morning will get your blood flowing and energize you. You can find countless tutorials on YouTube.
normalised: Firstly, Sun Salutations (Surya Namaskar) are a classic. Even just five rounds in the morning will get your blood flowing and energize you. You can find countless tutorials on YouTube.

unnormalised: Secondly, incorporate mindful breathing exercises (Pranayama). Anulom Vilom (alternate nostril breathing) is super easy to learn and do for 5-10 minutes daily. It helps calm the mind, which is great if you're feeling stressed from work or family drama (we all get that, right?).
normalised: Secondly, incorporate mindful breathing exercises (Pranayama). Anulom Vilom (alternate nostril breathing) is super easy to learn and do for five to ten minutes daily. It helps calm the mind, which is great if you're feeling stressed from work or family drama (we all get that, right?).

unnormalised: Thirdly, incorporate basic asanas. Tadasana (Mountain Pose), Vrikshasana (Tree Pose), and Adho Mukha Svanasana (Downward-Facing Dog) are good starting points. You can do them in a small space - even in your room in a 100 sq ft apartment! Remember to listen to your body and don't push yourself too hard.
normalised: Thirdly, incorporate basic asanas. Tadasana (Mountain Pose), Vrikshasana (Tree Pose), and Adho Mukha Svanasana (Downward-Facing Dog) are good starting points. You can do them in a small space - even in your room in a one hundred square foot apartment! Remember to listen to your body and don't push yourself too hard.

unnormalised: Finally, end your practice with a short Savasana (Corpse Pose) – even just 5 minutes lying still can be incredibly restorative. Think of it as a mini-vacation!
normalised: Finally, end your practice with a short Savasana (Corpse Pose) – even just five minutes lying still can be incredibly restorative. Think of it as a mini-vacation!

unnormalised: Pro-tip: Check if there are any local yoga classes near you. Maybe a branch of Patanjali Yogpeeth? Having a teacher guide you initially can be very beneficial. Dr. Sharma down the street from me runs some excellent sessions. It usually costs around Rs. 500 per class. Trust me, it's worth the investment in your well-being. You can even practice simple stretches while watching your favourite Bollywood film. Shanti!
